courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Introduction to Food Science and Technology

meetings.instructor: Dr. Erika KWEK,   Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor LI Cheng
Dr. Erika KWEK,   Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor LI Cheng
Dr. Erika KWEK,   Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor LI Cheng

courses.description: This course will provide an overview of various topics in food science and technology. Lectures will include discussions of general areas of interest chosen to stimulate and foster students' interest in both food science and food technology. The course will cover topics that include basic food chemistry, food processing and preservation, food microbiology and fermentation, food safety and toxicology, food engineering, food biotechnology, food evaluation and product development, etc. Relevant examples will be cited to strengthen the basic understanding of the principles in each topic. Local issues related to food will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: BCHE2030 & BIOL2120.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Nutrition for Health

meetings.instructor: Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Ms. YIP Pui Sze,   Professor CHOW Hei Man,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Ms. YIP Pui Sze,   Professor CHOW Hei Man,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Ms. YIP Pui Sze,   Professor CHOW Hei Man,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Ms. YIP Pui Sze,   Professor CHOW Hei Man,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack

courses.description: This course provides an overview of the basic concepts and principles of nutrition science and how to apply the principles of good nutrition in everyday life to the planning of healthy eating for optimal health, performance and disease prevention. Students will also be able to identify some common Hong Kong nutrition problems and the role of nutrition in their origins, prevention and therapy. The course will also expose the students to some additional nutritional issues of current health or research significance.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: FNSC2001.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Ethics and Professionalism for Nutritionists

meetings.instructor: Ms. YIP Pui Sze
Ms. YIP Pui Sze
Ms. YIP Pui Sze

courses.description: Ethics are principles that governing a personâ€™s professional behaviour. Students need to understand what is and what is not professional behaviour. Therefore, this course will cover the issues of professional behavior, including Association for Nutrition (AfN) Standards for Ethics, Conduct and Performance. Other topics relating to professionalism, such as intellectual property issues, preventing from corruption behavior, handling of privacy/personal data, etc. will also be covered in this course.To apply for the Nutritionist stream (FNS-NS), students must pass the course with at least a C in this course along with other FNS-NS admission requirements.

courses.title: Food Science Laboratory I

courses.description: This laboratory course accompanies FNSC3110 and 3180. This course introduces fundamental principles, methodologies and techniques currently used in food microbiological tests and food composition analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: FNSC3110.

courses.title: Nutritional Science Laboratory I

courses.description: This course is a laboratory counterpart of FNSC3010, 3030 and 4150. It is designed to train students in laboratory skills commonly used in research of nutritional biochemistry, relationship of nutrition and human development, and medical nutrition therapy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FNSC3030. Co-requisite: FNSC3010.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Nutrition and Human Development

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
meetings.instructor: Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor LI Cheng

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
meetings.instructor: Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor LI Cheng

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
meetings.instructor: Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor LI Cheng

courses.description: Since our body is experiencing changes in the life cycle, the nutrition needs would be different in various stages. This course describes the basis of these needs. Furthermore, the assessment of nutrient intake and physiology of our body in different life-cycle stages will be discussed. Prevention of chronic diseases through prudent dietary practices will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: FNSC3030. Co-requisite: FNSC3002.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Nutritional Biochemistry

meetings.instructor: Professor CHEN Zhefan,   Professor CHOW Hei Man

courses.description: This component will provide students with the background required to appreciate the biochemical aspects of nutrition and the impact of nutrition-related factors on normal human biochemistry.Â  Areas covered include the digestion and absorption of nutrients, energy intake and expenditure, nutrition and metabolism of carbohydrate, cholesterol synthesis and homeostasis, metabolism of dietary fats and their effect on lipoprotein cholesterol, nitrogen metabolism, and minerals and vitamins and their roles in biochemical processes.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Food Chemistry and Analysis

meetings.instructor: Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor LI Cheng
Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor LI Cheng

courses.description: This course will cover the basic chemical and analytical aspects of major food components (water, carbohydrates, lipids and proteins) and minor food components (vitamins, minerals, pigments and food additives including flavors, colorants and preservatives). Emphasis will be made on the chemical reactions and changes in these food constituents during processing, handling and storage. The principles and applications of chemical and instrumental analysis of food will be illustrated. The actions and applications of enzymes in food manufacture and food spoilage will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: FNSC3001.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Food Microbiology

meetings.instructor: Dr. LI Yuk Man
Dr. LI Yuk Man
Dr. LI Yuk Man
Dr. LI Yuk Man
Dr. LI Yuk Man
Dr. LI Yuk Man
Dr. LI Yuk Man

courses.description: This course considers the microorganisms in food safety, spoilage, and production. Topics discussed include food-borne disease agents and their control, food sanitation/hygiene, growth parameters of food spoilage agents, destruction of microbes in food, food fermentations, and the biotechnology of microbes as a resource for the food industry.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Food Science Laboratory II

meetings.instructor: Dr. WONG Tsz Yan
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan

Dr. WONG Tsz Yan
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan

courses.description: This is an integrated laboratory course for the food product production, which is composed of three interrelated areas, namely, food processing technology, food product development and food quality control. Through the food processing practicum, the principles, techniques and applications of conventional food processing technologies and equipment are introduced. Topics include frying, packaging, dehydration, concentration, sterilization, fermentation, protein coagulation, emulsification, baking, dough formation and candy making. This course also covers the techniques in formal sensory evaluation, and the principles of the common instruments for physical and chemical analyses of food quality. Besides, it contains an interactive workshop to explore the procedures in food product development in the contemporary catering and food industries.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: FNSC4110. Co-requisite: FNSC4170.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Nutritional Science Laboratory II

meetings.instructor: Ms. YIP Pui Sze

courses.description: The laboratory course provides practical skills acquire for works of clinical and community nutrition.Â  The topics in this laboratory course require students to apply science knowledge into practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: FNSC4120.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Human Physiology for Nutrition Studies I

meetings.instructor: Dr. CHOY Siu Wah,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. CHOY Siu Wah,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. CHOY Siu Wah,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack

courses.description: This course is the first part of a two-semester physiology series.Â  This course covers the main physiological systems of the human body.Â  By the completion of these courses, students should understand how the organ systems taught in our body function and regulate; they should be able to describe in detail how the taught organs work together to maintain homeostasis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken BIOL3630 or FNSC5130. Pre-requisite: LSCI1002 or LSCI1003.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Human Physiology for Nutrition Studies II

meetings.instructor: Dr. Erika KWEK,   Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. Erika KWEK,   Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. Erika KWEK,   Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. Erika KWEK,   Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack

courses.description: This course is a continuation of a two-semester physiology series.Â  This physiology course complements the other organ systems taught in the first semester.Â  By the completion of these courses, students should have the whole picture of the organ systems in our body; they should be able to describe in detail how these organs work together to maintain homeostasis, thus keeping us alive and healthy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken BCHE4130 or FNSC5320. Pre-requisite: FNSC4101.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Food Technology

meetings.instructor: Dr. Erika KWEK,   Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor CHUNG Hau Yin,   Professor LI Cheng

courses.description: In this course, students will examine the principles behind food processing technology, different kinds of conventional equipments and their effects on the sensory, microbiological and nutritional qualities of food e.g. meats, vegetable, fruits. Topics may also include food processing, waste management, etc., and basic principles of food engineering.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Community Nutrition

meetings.instructor: Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Ms. YIP Pui Sze

courses.description: Community nutrition recognizes that the control and prevention of nutrition problems are not merely biomedical in nature, but are embedded in the community of the affected individuals. A community nutritionist assesses and monitors not only physiological and dietary, but also social, cultural, technological and psychological information from many sources to determine needs and identify opportunities for sound, appropriate interventions that improve nutritional health. Because well-conceived nutrition surveys are basic tools for prioritising problems and deciding program plans and evaluations to provide better nutrition services to the public, the course will first introduce community nutrition survey design to the students. Making healthier choices, however, requires lifelong change in thinking and action at both individual and community levels. The rest of the course examines applications of current individual and group nutritional behaviour change theories to promote healthier diets.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Introduction to Medical Nutrition Therapy

meetings.instructor: Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor TSANG Suk Ying

courses.description: Medical nutrition therapy examines the theory and practice behind the prevention and treatment of diseases with the help of diet. This course will introduce the etiology and dietary management of selected diet-related diseases including obesity; anorexia and other eating disorders; diabetes mellitus; cardiovascular diseases including hyperlipidemias; diseases of the alimentary canal, liver, kidney and gall bladder; pancreatitis; food allergy and cancer. It will also cover nutritional management for AIDS patients, interaction of drugs and nutrients, and aspects of dietary therapy in Chinese Medicine. The related applied aspects of dietetics, including the practical skills associated with the preparation, use and evaluation of special diets, and the development of interview and communication skills, will also be covered.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Nutrition Planning and Food Policy

meetings.instructor: Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. YIP Pui Sze
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. YIP Pui Sze
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. YIP Pui Sze
Dr. WONG Tsz Yan,   Ms. YIP Pui Sze

courses.description: This course explores the emergence of food and nutrition policies from their multisectoral agricultural, population, health, environmental, economic, technological and political origins. The class will examine case studies from the international arena, focusing on Asian regional and local food and nutrition policy developments. Because nutrition promotion to the public is an integral component of these policies, a final portion of this course is devoted to the design of effective nutrition promotion and communication strategies for specific groups, including needs assessment, planning, implementation and evaluation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: FNSC4120.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Food Product Development and Quality Control

meetings.instructor: Professor LI Cheng
Professor LI Cheng
Professor LI Cheng

courses.description: This course explores various stages of food product development, and the importance of quality assurance. Topics include idea development, taste-panelling,Â  shelflife, local food regulations, the ISO standards, GMP, HACCP, quality control tools, statistic quality control and product evaluation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: FNSC4110.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Senior Experimental Project I
courses.description: In this course, students carry out an independent laboratory research project either provided by the supervisor or jointly decided with the student.Â  To fulfill the course requirement, students are required to discuss their progress with their supervisors regularly and submit a research proposal.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Senior Experimental Project II
courses.description: In this course, students continue to work on the research project from FNSC4901 or freshly start a new research project.Â  Students are required to discuss their progress with their supervisor(s) regularly and submit a progress report at the end of the term.Â  The report is assessed for performance.Â  Students must take FNSC4903 in 2nd term.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Senior Experimental Project III
courses.description: In this course, students continue to work on and finish up the research project from FNSC4902.Â  Relevant data analysis and conclusion formulation are performed after discussion with supervisors.Â  A final report in the form of a manuscript and an oral presentation are assessed at the end of the term for assessment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: FNSC4902.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Internship

meetings.instructor: Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter

courses.description: In this course, students have the opportunity to gain practical experience working in the government, private companies or non-government organizations.Â  Internship projects can be held either locally or overseas, and must be approved by the Programme.Â  Students are required to serve at least 160 hours and submit a written report for assessment.

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Nutrition Practicum

meetings.instructor: Ms. YIP Pui Sze
Ms. YIP Pui Sze
Ms. YIP Pui Sze
Ms. YIP Pui Sze

courses.description: This course is specifically designed for final-year Nutritionist Stream students in FNS Programme. Students should have completed FNSC4906 Internship prior to taking this course. The course aim is to reinforce experiential learning experience and further equip students with skills necessary to enter the workplace in the field of nutrition. The students are required to perform 2 to 3 different nutritional tasks, on campus or off campus, in more than one setting. These tasks may include, but not limit to, giving nutritional talks to the public, organizing nutrition activities for specific groups, communicating health to the general population, etc.Students are expected to apply scientific evidence-based nutrition knowledge and to carry out the task with the demonstration of professional behavior and the compliance in the code of ethics and standards of professional conduct. All experiential learning activities must be executed and scrutinized under the supervision of a registered dietitian or a registered nutritionist.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: FNSC4906

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Students shall be required to present the results of their research to their peers and staff.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Food & Nutritional Sciences

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Chemical, Physical and Microbiological Characteristics of Food

meetings.instructor: Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor CHUNG Hau Yin
Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor CHUNG Hau Yin

courses.description: This course applies the knowledge of the physical and chemical behavior of food components in the context of food manufacturing and storage, with emphasis on both safety and nutritional attributes. It also aims at developing chemical, microbiological and sensory analyses to assess the quality and safety of foods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Food and Nutritional Sciences or MSc Nutrition, Food Science and Technology Not for students who have taken LSCI5811

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Nutrition and the Challenge of Non-communicable Disease

meetings.instructor: Ms LEE Yik Han Helen,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHEN Zhenyu,   Professor TSANG Suk Ying
Ms LEE Yik Han Helen,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHEN Zhenyu,   Professor TSANG Suk Ying

courses.description: This course explores the origins and etiology, dietary therapies and population-based strategies to overcome the nutrition-related chronic disease burden globally, regionally and in Hong Kong. Multidisciplinary researchers and practitioners will discuss how modern culture, including food consumption and lifestyles, produces this noncommunicable disease burden, leaving governments challenged to fnd effective policy solutions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Food and Nutritional Sciences or MSc Nutrition, Food Science and Technology Not for students who have taken LSCI5812

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Students shall be required to present the results of their research to their peers and staff.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Food & Nutritional Sciences

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Food Processing Technology and Food Biotechnology

meetings.instructor: Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor CHUNG Hau Yin
Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor CHUNG Hau Yin
Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHEUNG Chi Keung Peter,   Professor CHUNG Hau Yin

courses.description: This course reviews the causes of food spoilage and quality loss. Principles and effects of traditional food processing and food preservation technology on food quality will be covered. New and emerging processing technology will also be covered. The course highlights the latest industrial applications of food biotechnology with emphasis on the production of food and food products through molecular biology, bioprocess engineering and microbial biotechnology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Food and Nutritional Sciences or MSc Nutrition, Food Science and Technology Not for students who have taken LSCI5821

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Nutrition and Immunity across the Life Span

meetings.instructor: Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHOW Hei Man,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack

courses.description: This module covers various aspects of nutrition, ranging from biochemistry to nutrition for the lifespan. The content aims to integrate fundamental knowledge into dietary practices in everyday life. The development and prevention of chronic diseases in the context of nutrition will also be discussed. Recent popular topics, such as obesity, trans fat, etc, are also introduced. At the end of this module, students should be able to state the basic biological mechanisms in maintaining a body through good nutrition.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Food and Nutritional Sciences or MSc Nutrition, Food Science and Technology Not for students who have taken LSCI5822

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Students shall be required to present the results of their research to their peers and staff.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Food & Nutritional Sci

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Nutritional Physiology

meetings.instructor: Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHOW Hei Man
Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHOW Hei Man
Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHOW Hei Man
Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor CHOW Hei Man

courses.description: In this course, the physiological aspects of nutrition will be introduced. The course covers how nutrients may affect human physiologically in an organ-specific manner. Malnutrition can be interpreted as over- or under-nutrition. Together with the basic understanding of human anatomy and physiology, the pathophysiological impact of malnourishment will be discussed. Gastrointestinal, renal, cardiovascular, respiratory and endocrine systems will be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Nutrition, Food Science and Technology or MPhil-PhD Food and Nutritional Sciences  Course Exclusion: LSCI5832

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Applied Nutrition

meetings.instructor: Dr. CHUNG Susan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor TSANG Suk Ying,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. CHUNG Susan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor TSANG Suk Ying,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack
Dr. CHUNG Susan,   Ms. SIN Man Ching,   Professor TSANG Suk Ying,   Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack

courses.description: This course presents applied aspects of nutrition with emphasis on research and development in functional foods, nutritional values of traditional Chinese herbs and sports nutrition, fitness and weight management, with a view to enhance health status and quality of life. Each of these areas addresses a specific issue that is the interest of public and presents the progress in these exciting new researches.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Food and Nutritional Sciences or MSc Nutrition, Food Science and Technology Not for students who have taken LSCI5842

courses.subject: FNSC
courses.title: Food Toxicology & Safety

meetings.instructor: Dr. LI Yuk Man,   Mr CHEUNG Chi Leung

courses.description: Food can be contaminated at any stage of its production and handling with naturally occurring toxicants and/or man-made chemicals that have adverse health effects to humans. The objective of this course is to gain knowledge on the key concepts and principles of food safety and toxicology. Students are expected to develop an understanding of the nature and properties of the toxic substances in foods as well as the nature and magnitude of the hazard they represent to humans, with the aim of preventing health risks due to food intake. Topics on food safety include food hygiene, food poisoning, food legislation and food safety control systems. Topics on food toxicology include its general principles, biochemical and physiological mechanisms of action of food toxicants, and methods for food safety assessment. Emphasis will be placed on the evaluation of current issues in food safety toxicology including risk assessment and management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Nutrition, Food Science and Technology or MPhil-PhD Food and Nutritional Sciences or BSc Food and Nutritional Sciences Not for students who have taken LSCI5843

Each student is required to submit a written progress report about his or her research on completion of the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Nutrition, Food Science and Technology
